screens.headline: You just lost $150 before the trade even moved
screens.text: You bought an option for $2.20. Instantly checked to sell it - only $1.80 offered. You lost $40 (18%) in 3 seconds. The stock didn't move. The market didn't crash. You just got hit by the hidden tax: the bid-ask spread.

screens.headline: Bid, Ask, and the Spread Between Them
screens.text: Every option has TWO prices. BID = what buyers will pay you (you sell here). ASK = what sellers want (you buy here). SPREAD = Ask - Bid = the cost of trading. Market makers profit from this difference. Wide spreads = expensive trading.

cards.definition: The HIGHEST price buyers offer - where YOU sell
cards.example: Bid $4.90 means you sell for $4.90/share = $490 total

cards.definition: The LOWEST price sellers want - where YOU buy
The difference (Ask - Bid) = your cost to trade

screens.headline: Think of it like a currency exchange
screens.text: You're at the airport exchanging dollars for euros. Two windows show different rates...

reveal_sections.label: Window A: Tight Spread (Bank)
reveal_sections.content: Buy euros at $1.08, sell euros at $1.06. Spread = $0.02 (2%). Fair deal - you lose 2% to exchange.

reveal_sections.label: Window B: Wide Spread (Airport Kiosk)
reveal_sections.content: Buy euros at $1.20, sell at $0.90. Spread = $0.30 (29%!). Ripoff - you lose 29% instantly. Avoid!

reveal_sections.label: Options spreads work the same way
reveal_sections.content: Tight spread (<5%) = fair market. Wide spread (>10%) = you're getting robbed by market makers. Always check before buying!

screens.question: An option shows: Bid $2.00, Ask $2.10, Mid $2.05. You buy at ask. Stock doesn't move. You immediately sell. How much did you lose?
options: $0 - no loss if stock didn't move
screens.explanation_correct: Exactly! You bought at $2.10 (ask), sold at $2.00 (bid) = $0.10 loss per share Ã— 100 shares = $10 loss per contract. This is slippage - the cost of the spread. On a $205 position, you lost $10 = 4.9% instantly. Always factor this in!
screens.explanation_wrong: You bought at ASK ($2.10) and sold at BID ($2.00). That's $0.10 difference Ã— 100 shares = $10 per contract lost to the spread. The stock didn't move, but you paid the 'spread tax' twice (once buying, once selling).

screens.question: Which option is MORE liquid and safer to trade?
screens.explanation_correct: Perfect! Option B has a $0.20 spread (4% on midpoint) = tight, liquid, fair market. Option A has $3 spread (67% on midpoint!) = illiquid nightmare. You'd lose $300 per contract just entering and exiting. ALWAYS choose tight spreads!
screens.explanation_wrong: Look at the spread as % of price. Option B: $0.20 spread on ~$5 = 4% (excellent). Option A: $3 spread on ~$4.50 = 67% (disaster!). Wide spreads destroy your profits before the trade even moves. Avoid Option A!

screens.question: You found a perfect trade setup, but the bid is $2.00 and ask is $3.50. What should you do?
options: Buy at ask anyway - the setup is perfect
Place limit order at midpoint ($2.75) and wait
Skip the trade - spread is too wide (43%)
Use a market order to guarantee execution
screens.explanation_correct: Smart discipline! $1.50 spread on $2.75 midpoint = 54% spread. You'd lose $150 per contract just trading in and out. Even if your thesis is right, the spread will eat your profits. NEVER trade options with >10% spreads. Find a more liquid alternative!
screens.explanation_wrong: Spread = $1.50 on ~$2.75 midpoint = 54%. That's TOXIC. Even if the stock moves perfectly for you, half your theoretical profit goes to the spread. No trade setup is worth a 54% entry tax. Walk away and find liquid options (SPY, QQQ, AAPL, TSLA).

screens.question: Where are the TIGHTEST spreads usually found?
options: Far OTM weekly options on small-cap stocks
ATM monthly options on SPY, AAPL, MSFT
Deep ITM options on any stock
screens.explanation_correct: Exactly! ATM options on mega-cap stocks (SPY, QQQ, AAPL, MSFT, TSLA, NVDA) have massive volume = tight spreads (often $0.01-0.05). Market makers compete for these trades. Monthly expirations are more liquid than weeklies. This is where beginners should trade!
screens.explanation_wrong: Liquidity follows volume. ATM options = most traders = tightest spreads. Mega-cap stocks = most traders = best liquidity. Monthly expirations = standard = most liquid. Far OTM and small caps = wide spreads = avoid until you're experienced.

cards.back: The 'hidden tax' of options trading. BID = where you sell. ASK = where you buy. The difference is your cost to trade. Market makers profit from spreads.
Target: <5% of option price. Acceptable: <10% if necessary. AVOID: >10% (you're getting robbed). Calculate: (Ask-Bid) Ã· Midpoint Ã— 100%.
1) Trade mega-cap stocks (SPY, AAPL, MSFT). 2) Trade ATM or slightly OTM strikes. 3) Use monthly expirations. 4) Check spread BEFORE buying. 5) Use limit orders, never market orders!
